fr.reflexe.viewshell.api.design

Interface IPageAssetGroup

  • All Superinterfaces:
    Iterable<IPageAsset>

    public interface IPageAssetGroup
extends Iterable<IPageAsset>
    Defines a group of related page assets, such as a set of stylesheets or a set of files defining a scripting framework.

    The group may be indissociable, meaning that attaching one member of the group automatically implicitly attaches all other members of the group. In all other cases, the group simply defines a set of resources that may be used together, without necessarily requiring all resources in the group.

    Note: groups are not themselves attachable. In this way, a newer version of an implementation of a IPageAsset can be refactored into a set of resources, and (if the attachment was defined without specifying the version), then all related indissociable resources will automatically be linked.

    Groups can be used directly in for-each constructs, to iterate over assets.

    Groups do not need to be registered as OSGi services.

    Thread safety: implementations are expected to be immutable and completely thread-safe.

    Since:
    1.0
    Author:
    REFLEXE Technologies

    • Method Detail

      • isIndissociable

        boolean isIndissociable()
        Indicates if the resources in this group are indissociable. When indissociable, then attachment of one resource implies automatic implicit attachment of all other resources in the same group.
        Returns:
        true if the group's resources are indissociable, or false if they may be used independently.
        Since:
        1.0

      • getGroupName

        String getGroupName()
        Gets the technical (locale-independent) name for the group.
        Returns:
        the group name.
        Since:
        1.0

      • getAssets

        List<IPageAsset> getAssets()
        Gets the list of asset that belong to this group. All asset in the group should refer to the group.
        Returns:
        a list of unique assets, possibly empty but never null.
        Since:
        1.0
        See Also:
        Iterable.iterator()
